Key Arguments: The bill undermines the fundamental right to freedom of speech.
It creates two classes of citizens, privileging politicians, journalists, and educational institutions over regular citizens.
The legislation risks undermining the democratic power of the internet.
Excessive fines will lead to more restrictive digital services.
Determining truth is complex and historically fluid, making the bill's approach problematic.
The bill targets not only false information but also true information deemed misleading or deceptive.
International enforcement issues could limit Australians' access to diverse social media networks.
Delegating legislative power to private entities violates constitutional freedoms.
The bill could undermine the democratic process by categorizing certain political viewpoints as misinformation.
The legislation lacks consideration for the experiences and viewpoints of ordinary Australians.
Notable Quotes: The internet has allowed regular people to have a voice and participate in shaping our democracy.
The task of accurately determining what is true or untrue is impossible.
Freedom of speech is vital as it allows for open and honest discussions, even when perspectives differ.
This bill would stifle or, I fear, destroy this natural and healthy way of the growth of knowledge and information.
